posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked:
Dear CD,

I am reaching out to seek some technical advice from individuals who might have more expertise than I do. Over the weekend, we encountered a failure on our CANbus due to a broken wire in our “energy chain” that leads to the elevator. The damage likely stemmed from pinching or excessive bending, as the wire was a simple twisted pair (two separate wires). We are considering replacing it with jacketed cable, possibly from Igus.

The best option available is a 4-conductor cable. However, since we only require two wires for the elevator, I’m wondering whether it would be better to crimp the wires in pairs (creating a redundant system) or to keep them separate, with the second wire acting as a backup. On one hand, crimping the wires together would provide immediate redundancy, potentially saving time in case of a single wire break. On the other hand, if a wire breaks within a crimped pair, it could cause signal reflections, which might lead to challenging diagnostic issues on the CAN bus, especially in FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) robots with limited devices and relatively short communication paths.

I’m unsure about how sensitive CAN systems are to such problems under these specific conditions. Do you have any insights or experiences that could help guide this decision?

Best regards,  
[Your Name]

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version:

I doubt you over-cycled a wire properly contained in an energy chain in a single FRC season, unless you are doing 100 times more drive practice than a typical team.

In your situation, I'd be inclined to terminate the wires as two independent twisted pair runs (assuming you buy a cable assembly with two twisted pairs), allowing for the possibility of a rapid switch from one to the other in the pits.

Then decide if you wanted to combine those into parallel runs outside of the terminations, perhaps doing an experiment to see what happens if you only connect one half of one of the pairs and leave the other wire unconnected. (My suspicion is that it will work just fine at 1 Mbps CAN, but testing beats guessing.)

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked: CAN is sensitive to electrical noise, and relies on specific electromagnetic interactions between the signal+ and signal- lines that make a **twisted pair** a necessity. Are the conductors in your chosen cable twisted pairs? Additionally, a single pair of parallel wires that are not twisted can be problematic, and adding another non-twisted pair in parallel only exacerbates the issue by increasing signal integrity degradation due to mutual coupling between the wires. This can lead to rounding off of the relatively fast transitions during the rising and falling edges of the signal, potentially causing data loss within the CAN frame. All of this underscores the importance of ensuring that twisted pairs are used. While parallel twisted pairs may not inherently be terrible, straight wires placed in parallel are more likely to cause issues over a longer run within an IGUS chain.

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked: The cable we are looking at is 4-conductor twisted wires with braided shielding. Although it could technically be called "shielded twisted quad," we will use it as a single-pair cable, meaning the bus will not run through it. Consequently, this setup should reduce noise compared to the typical unshielded wires we often use, despite employing them ourselves.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked: The user mentioned an Ethernet cable. They were about to suggest a simple one for cost reasons but noted that @prensing was concerned about potential stress fractures from repeated bending, especially since Ethernet cables are typically made of solid copper wire, which is more prone to work-hardening failures. @prensing questioned whether the broken wire occurred during movement or under tension, and also asked about the specific gauge of the wire. They pointed out that smaller wires generally take longer to fail due to work-hardening compared to thicker gauges, referencing @sokoloff's earlier comment.

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked:
e that broke was 22 AWG silicone "flex" wire. I did not see it myself. It was in the middle of the chain, and there probably was an element of it getting pulled out from lying smooth, maybe getting pinched, etc. So definitely, the first order effect would be having something jacketed so that the wires have a harder time separating and getting pinched. The power wires do not seem to have such an issue. ``` The user has provided a query where they want me to clean up some text by removing HTML tags and unnecessary elements. I did not see it myself. It was in the middle of the chain, and there probably was an element of it getting pulled out from lying smooth, maybe getting pinched, etc. So definitely, the first-order effect would be having something jacketed so that the wires have a harder time separating and getting pinched. The power wires do not seem to have such an issue.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: I believe Ethernet patch cables are generally stranded, whereas the building wire used for Ethernet is typically solid.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: In the past, we had issues with Ethernet wires in our elevators breaking down. This was true for both solid and stranded cables. Currently, we're successfully using Hi-flex cables sourced from Automation Direct without any problems. Additionally, Automation Direct offers a $50 voucher under their "Kit of Parts."
While I think it is overkill, I will say that IGUS Chainflex stuff is both premium and indestructible.
West Coast Products sells jacketed Controller Area Network (CAN) wires, which might just be the easiest option to prevent future issues: 22AWG CAN Wire (Jacketed, 25-feet) – WestCoast Products.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked: I'd also recommend more robust wire and/or setting things up for quick swapping. If you create parallel transmission lines, you'll end up changing the effective impedance, which could cause reflections, among other issues. If this is the roboRIO CAN bus, it might be okay. This issue can arise in some CAN topologies, which is why higher-speed CAN buses often prefer a bus topology.

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: Do you have a link or product number for the AD cable? Thanks.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: We are using Q5922-1 Quabbin continuous flexing Cat6/6a industrial Ethernet cable, shielded, 4 twisted pairs, 24 AWG, 7-stranded, tinned copper conductor with polyethylene insulation material, TPE jacket, teal in color. This cable is available for purchase online at https://www.automationdirect.com/adc/shopping/catalog/bulk_wire_-a-_cable/data_-a-_communication_cable/q5922-1.
